channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Amartya Sen on Why India Trails China
item.description: The provision of essential services to its population is where India lags the most behind China argues Amartya Sen, a Nobel laureate and a professor of economics and philosophy at Harvard University.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Amartya Sen during a talk in New Delhi on Dec. 15, 2005.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Teaching Science, in Chinese, From Space
item.description: Teaching from space like an American female astronaut six years ago, Wang Yaping of China told students she couldn’t see any U.F.O.’s as she showed how water, pendulums and gyroscopes behaved in weightless conditions.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: CCTV, via Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Chinese astronaut Wang Yaping, with a water ball she made in space, during a lecture to students on Earth from the Tiangong-1 space module.

item.title: Oil Wealth Reduced, Russia Needs to Lure Foreign Capital
item.description: Foreign investors, wary of endemic corruption and an expanding government role in the economy, are hanging back, depriving Russia’s economy of essential capital.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Without vast oil profits to hide economic problems, Vladimir V. Putin’s iron fist could be the biggest obstacle to badly needed restructuring, analysts say.

item.title: Gyula Horn, Helped Part Iron Curtain, Dies at 80
item.description: As Moscow’s grip on Eastern Europe slipped, Mr. Horn proved nimble as a newly minted, nonideological, pragmatic reformer in helping to lead Hungary away from Communism.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Gyula Horn, right, of Hungary, and Alois Mock of Austria cut the barbed wire on the border with Austria on June 27, 1989.

item.title: Taliban Talks Could Depend on Detainees
item.description: Five prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, could be the key to whether the negotiations the United States has long sought with the Taliban are a success, or even take place.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: The five Taliban prisoners in the proposed exchange are from top left: Mohammad Nabi Omari, Abdul Haq Wasiq, Mullah Norullah Noori, Mullah Mohammad Fazl, Khirullah Said Wali Khairkhwa.

item.title: Global Sell-off Shows Fed Reach Beyond the U.S.
item.description: Tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world in recent weeks are demonstrating just how reliant the global economy has become on the policies of the Federal Reserve.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Traders at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, a day when the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell 2.5 percent.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenyan President’s Trial Pushed Back
item.description: The International Criminal Court has pushed back the start of the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya until Nov. 12 to give defense lawyers time to prepare.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Life Sentence in Sweden for Genocide Case
item.description: A Swedish court on Thursday sentenced a man of Rwandan origin to life in prison for his role in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Turkish Liberals Turn Their Backs on Erdogan
item.description: For an urban elite, including some protesters, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to demonstrations has led to a final break that began with his intimidation of the news media.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former supporters of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan say his response to the Taksim Square protests was the final straw.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany Blocks Turkey’s European Union Talks
item.description: A diplomat said Thursday that Germany had blocked the next step in the European Union’s membership talks with Turkey over the government’s crackdown on street protests this month.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Top Tax Official Arrested in Venezuela
item.description: President Nicolas Maduro said about $630,000 was seized after a search of the unidentified official’s “luxurious” apartment in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Europe’s Finance Ministers Start Negotiating Guidelines on Failing Banks
item.description: European Union finance ministers began two days of talks in Luxembourg on regulations aimed at promoting financial security, but the meetings could be overshadowed by renewed concerns in Greece.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Finance Minister Yannis Stournaras of Greece, left, and his Irish counterpart, Michael Noonan.

item.title: World Briefing | Science And Health: One-Third of Women Assaulted by a Partner, Global Report Says
item.description: Experts said screening for domestic violence should be added to all levels of health care.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Dispute Over Falklands Intensifies
item.description: More than 30 years after the Argentines invaded the islands and British forces retook them, the emotions of the dispute appear to be reinvigorated.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Documents Detail Restrictions on N.S.A. Surveillance
item.description: Government documents supplied by the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden and published on Thursday draw a sharp distinction between “U.S. persons” and foreigners.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Philippines Warns That It May Pull Peacekeepers Out of Golan
item.description: The warning, made by President Benigno S. Aquino III, came as the United Nations was still scrambling for replacements to fill a void in the force left by Austria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sweeping Protests in Brazil Pull In an Array of Grievances
item.description: A country once viewed as a stellar example of an ascendant democratic power has been upended by an uprising with one theme: an angry rejection of politics as usual.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Military Says Law Barring U.S. Aid to Rights Violators Hurts Training Mission
item.description: Some top military commanders say the law undermines their ability to train foreign troops to fight militants and drug traffickers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Nearing One Year In, Egypt’s Leader Is Besieged by Critics
item.description: As the first anniversary of Mohamed Morsi’s inauguration as president approaches, he faces widespread discontent and grass-roots campaigns that have undermined his ability to wield power.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Cairo, unhappy with President Mohamed Morsi, have occupied the offices of his new culture minister, preventing him from entering.

item.title: Palestinian Premier Submits Resignation After Just Two Weeks in Office
item.description: The resignation of Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah was a sign of continuing internal political disarray amid already complicated American efforts to restart the peace process with Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The new prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Rami Hamdallah, lasted only two weeks in office.

item.title: Czech Premier Candidate Seen as Honest but Inexperienced
item.description: Miroslava Nemcova, the speaker of the House in the country’s lower house of Parliament, was nominated by the Civic Democrats to replace the departing prime minister, Petr Necas.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Jagr’s Cup Pursuit Keeps Fans in Prague Awake
item.description: Seven players in the Stanley Cup finals are Slovak or Czech, including hockey great Jaromir Jagr, igniting interest in the series among fans in Slovakia and the Czech Republic.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN PINELLI
item.media:credit: Michal Novotny for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marko Aleksic, left, and the bartender David Povolny watching Game 4 at a pub in Prague.

item.title: Amsterdam Journal: The Dutch Prize Their Pedal Power, but a Sea of Bikes Swamps Their Capital
item.description: Bicycles, the preferred means of travel, are clogging streets and overwhelming parking spaces in Amsterdam, causing some to say the unthinkable: There are too many bikes.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN TAGLIABUE
item.media:credit: Pavel Prokopchik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amsterdam is trying to keep its hordes of bikes under control. In a city of 800,000, there are 880,000 bicycles, the government estimates, four times the number of cars.

item.title: Rosneft to Send $60 Billion Worth of Oil to China
item.description: The deal came after China lent the Russian state oil company millions in the last 10 years to complete its trans-Siberian pipeline.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: China’s vice premier, Zhang Gaoli, left, met Thursday with Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, to discuss a contract to supply China with crude oil.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Why Bernanke’s Remarks Set off Global, Contagious Market Fears
item.description: NEW YORK — As global markets tumbled and the Dow Jones Industrial Average headed for what could be its biggest percentage decline of the year, Rendezvous editor, Marcus Mabry, sat down with Nelson Schwartz and Nathaniel Popper, New York Times business reporters, to find out why.
item.dc:creator: By MARCUS MABRY
